151136957.review:
With amazing atmosphere thanks to imo one of the best soundtracks, a great art style and deep lore, this game will always have a special place in my heart. 
Admittedly, it was pretty frustrating in the start, especially since my old laptop was not able to register more than 2 inputs, which made nail bouncing quite a chore (I needed over a hundred attempts for the first mandatory boss). But after upgrading to more acceptable hard ware, I was rewarded handsomely. The many details of the world are absolutely worth spending the exploration time on, as well as is taking a moment to ponder the lore implications of the bits of information given by the unique characters and environment. 
There is also a lot of replay value thanks to multiple endings, a boss rush mode and an arena mode. 

If Silk Song is going to be at least half as great as the first Hollow Knight game, it is going to be well worth waiting for it a couple of years.

150968900.review:
1. Gameplay: This game makes me wonder if I subconsciously like suffering because the amount of time and effort I spent at certain bosses or platforming obstacles made me feel like an addicted masochist that keeps failing and coming back for more. Anyways, the movement and spells were smooth and satisfying to execute once I got the hang of the controls. 

2. Visuals, Sound, & Music: I really enjoyed the aesthetic art style, immersive sound effects, and fitting music soundtracks for different settings. In the midst of all the chaos happening in the game, many times I found myself exploring for spots to take pictures and leisurely enjoy the background music. It's also not surprising that a large chunk of my screenshots in my Steam library are from Hollow Knight. I've used some of those screenshots as my wallpapers/screensavers.

3. Plot: To avoid spoilers, all I will say is that the lore is pretty neat, bringing up thought-provoking discussion topics and theories. 

4. Entertainment Value: Even when I'm not spending time playing the game itself, I find myself sometimes spiraling down a rabbit hole as I search the internet and watch Youtube videos related to the game's lore, speedrunners, mods, memes, art, merch, etc.

150870448.review:
Honestly, I went into Hollow Knight knowing nothing other than it's a great game; one that all my friends recommended to me. I remember a friend in elementary school recommending it to me and I just shrugged it off. I picked Hollow Knight while it was on sale a little bit ago, and while the start is a little slow it was just fun. After beating the game with 64% I can confidently say that I cannot wait to 100% hollow Knight and that includes 63 out of 63 Achievements. Hollow Knight is something special and something that I think will stick with me no matter how far Hollow Knight or me goes. Hollow Knight is one of the best gaming experiences I have had in awhile, I loved Hollow Knight. Hollow Knight brought a new game genre to my mind that I had never tried, that being metroidvania style games. I liked Hollow Knight so much that I will certainly be around to buy Hollow Knight: Silksong on day one and I will probably buy both Ori games too, I love this genre now and I am so grateful for Team Cherry and their dedication to this game, they truly made an amazing game! 
So all that being said, I would say this is my second favorite game I have played and I would HIGHLY recommend this game to anyone contemplating. Just buy it. Play it. Beat it. And do it all over again.
12/10 is the rating I would give Hollow Knight. Thank you Team Cherry

TL:DR just buy the game it's only $15

This game is a masterpiece. The art is incredible, the music is ear candy, the story/lore is surprisingly good, but most importantly this game is fun as hell (if you enjoy difficult games). The combat is simple yet elegant. The exploration gets you excited even when you find a small relic to sell. The abilities are fun to master. The game has so many hours of content, especially on your first playthrough. It's also fun to replay in challenge runs, and there's plenty of endgame stuff if that's not your thing. 10/10 (however, it's a metroidvania so get prepared for some backtracking)

150395605.review:
Hollow Knight es mi segundo juego favorito después de Outer Wilds.

Es un Metroidvania que transcurre en una colonia subterránea de insectos. Existen distintas civilizaciones. Cuando el juego comienza la civilización de los insectos está en decadencia debido a un virus.

La historia es muy muy buena, es contada al estilo de los Dark Souls, dispersa. Lo que sí, es bastante difícil entenderla bien únicamente con el juego, me hubiera gustado que esté un poco más clara, y al mismo tiempo haberle (yo) prestado más atención a la historia mientras jugaba. Terminé viendo videos sobre la historia en YouTube para terminar de aclararla.

La jugabilidad es perfecta,  10/10, siempre que mueres sabes que es tu culpa, porque lo has jugado mal, ni por mala suerte ni por errores del juego. De verdad, es muy satisfactorio de jugar.

La dificultad también me encantó, escala de una manera muy buena. Mucha gente dice que es un juego difícil, pero yo no tardé más de un día en derrotar a algún jefe, menos con los jefes finales. Y es que fue el primer Metroidvania convencional que jugué. Yo diría que es medianamente difícil.

La variedad de enemigos y jefes es inmensa, y cada uno tiene sus distintos patrones, hay algunos que pasan desapercibidos, pero ten por seguro de que cuando termines el juego vas a rememorar a unos cuantos.

Yo creo que tardé 40 horas en completar el juego, pero se pueden seguir haciendo un montón de cosas luego de terminar lo principal, y he  de decir que en ningún momento me cansé de jugar.

Los gráficos personalmente me encantaron, tienen su propio estilo, no he encontrado ningún juego con gráficos similares.

La música es TREMENDA. Yo soy músico y he inspirado mucha de mi música en la de este juego. Acompaña perfectamente cada combate y cada momento y cuando la música tiene que parar, lo hace, es realmente admirable. Aún al día de hoy sigo escuchando su música a más de un año de jugar al juego (aunque cada tanto me hecho algún combatito)

Hay muchos tipos de personajes, algunos de que no te interesan, y otros de los que hubieras querido saber más, mucho más, cono en mi caso Quirrel.

Tanto los gráficos como la música, los personajes y los efectos sonoros permiten crear una atmósfera increíble, aunque el juego no sea realista, te mete completamente en su mundo.

Realmente creo que es el único juego que he jugado que me parece perfecto. No le he encontrado absolutamente nada que no me guste ni nada que cambiaría. Y justamente por eso tengo miedo de cómo pueda ser la secuela Silksong, es muy difícil superar a este juego, pero le tengo fe a Team Cherry.

Es un juego que (espero) va a pasar a la historia como un referente. 10/10 indiscutido.

150321366.review:
¿Hollow Knight?

Para el ciego, es la luz. Para el hambriento, es el pan. Para el enfermo, es la cura. Para el solitario, es un compañero. Para el prisionero, es la libertad. Para el pobre, es el tesoro. Para el deudor, es el perdón.

En el momento de escribir esta reseña, todavia no he logrado llegar al final, pero aun asi se convirtio en uno de mis videjuegos favoritos. Personalmente antes de comprarlo no sabia nada de este, y cuando lo compre decidi pasarmelo evadiendo cualquier tipo de guia, video, etc... relacionado a este, para poder tener la mejor experiencia 100% por si mismo, y descubriendo todo del mundo jugandolo. 
Cuando lo jugue por primera vez me atrapo rapidamente, TODO. Desde el estilo arististico, los controles, la dificultad, pienso que fue practicamente perfecto. Creo que cuando realmente cai en el amor con este juego fue cuando llegue al Sendero Verde por primera vez tras derrotar al caballero falso, ver esa zona, combinda con la hermosa musica, me hizo analizar lo grande que seria el juego, y tras unas 20 horas de juego sigo descubriendo cosas constantemente y cada una me sorprende mas que la anterior, llegar a la ciudad de las lagrimas me hizo genuinamente apreciar un poco la experiencia de jugarlo por primera vez, ya que cuando lo complete, sera la unica vez que pueda experimentar el juego de esa manera, y hasta cierto punto eso es lo que evita que lo juegue tanto.

Los aspectos destacables del juego diria que son practicamente todos.
El estilo artistico es el mejor que he visto en un videjuego, que haya jugado o no. La expresividad de los NPC's que hay, siendo que cada uno es unico, los enemigos, y por sobretodo el ambiente del lugar donde te encuentres, un nido de arañas a un camino completamente verde, o una mina de gemas, todas son visualmente complacientes y hermosas en todo el sentido de la palabra, el estilo gotico de lugares como la ciudad de las lagrimas realmente complementan excelentemente el resto de la estetica.

La musica como ya mencione en lugares como el sendero verde es hermosa al igual que toda la zona en general, acompaña muy bien a los lugares y no constrasta de mala manera con ellos, nada mas que decir.

La jugabilidad es increiblemente divertida, dinamica, facil de aprender pero dificil de masterizar, y es realmente un reto en peleas contra bosses, poder acercarte, esquivar o saber en que momento curarte con el ALMA, genuinamente muy disfrutable y comoda.

Espero que en lo que me queda de playtruth el videjuego no me decepcione, y la verdad que lo dudo, con todo lo que ya me ha mostrado, lo consideraria de los mejores, si no el mejor indie creado.

150292111.review:
Overall this is a very good Metroidvania game and I would rate it at least 9. I have a slight bad first impression on hollow knight since its characters are bug and I generally dont like bug, but after finishing it, now I can see why many people like it.

Positive:
Graphic is very good, background map are well drawn and bug characters are good and can be cute or scary.

Sound effect and OST, OST are good and suits each map, few are great such as city of Tears. Sound effect I must say, developer nails it, each character's sound effect suit them.

Gameplay, this is the core strength of HK, the Knight can be nimble and can have good attack depends on player skill and charm and nail upgrade. The knight is flexible, charms can be customized depends on player preference. If I am stuck in certain boss battle, I change its charms to suit certain boss battle.

Story, for me this part is just ok since story is not as straight forward like Ori but more like many small piece of puzzle consists of bit of story and hint that player needs to piece them to understand the real story. I didnt understand it so I read whole story from internet. A bit spoiler, the story is quite depressing and dark, there are many tragedies and there is no straight righteous main character. 

Map and game design, this is another strength of HK where it has extensive map, secrets. HK has many endings and developer provides free DLC that provides more replayability and challenges for hardcore players.

With all strengths being said, I have several issues:
1. Compass as charm. I agree compass need to be bought but I disagree compass as charm, compass is only used at the same time with map, while map is not required as charm.
2. There is no clear objective. I understand the game design to be exploration, but there is a time where I want to focus on main objective to progress the game, not just wander around aimless and figuring out whats the next objective. This is a waste of time.
3. A bit minor drawing issue, I think the mouth part can be improved. It looks a bit simple.
4. Game froze one time for me and cannot be reproduced.

For some reason I like to compare HK with Ori 2, after finishing both of them, HK wins a bit overall in terms of gameplay, exploration and replayability. But in term of wholesome and satisfaction, I prefer Ori 2 due to more wholesome straight story and HK story is somehow too dark and depressing for me.

Nevertheless kudo to team Cherry as small indie developers to create such great game, this is a great achivement for them.

PS: whoever design white palace map is a masochist, it is no wonder pale king stuck there :(

150132779.review:
In 2014, a small indie game developer group called Team Cherry was created. Programmer William Pellen and artist Ari Gibson wanted to create their own worlds to explore and conquer. This is how the game Hollow Knight was born. Hollow Knight is a metroidvania published in 2017 by Team Cherry. In the world of Hollow Knight, the player plays as a small knight where they can explore caves, fight challenging creatures and escape unexpected traps. The game is highly inspired by popular games such as Metroid, Zelda II: The Adventure of Link and Mega Man X.

Hollow Knight is set in an empty desolate realm of insects that lies beneath the surface of the earth. The player arrives in a small town called Dirtmouth, located just above the kingdom of Hallownest. Hallownest was once a thriving kingdom, but became infected by a supernatural virus. More and more citizens became infected and the Emperor of Hallownest, the Pale King, tried his best to lock the virus away within the Temple of the Black Egg. However, through all the efforts, the virus still managed to escape the temple and Hallownest fell into ruin. It is up to the player to investigate the secrets hidden deep within the kingdom and try to stop the virus. The player must run around and explore every corner of Hallownest. Within the game, you learn the history of Hallownest through ancient runes and dialogue from the few remaining citizens. It's almost like reading between the lines of a book or putting together a puzzle to get the whole picture. On your travels, you'll find fun and unique NPCs to talk to and infected enemies to fight.

In Hollow Knight you run around as a small knight-like character. The player uses a sword-like weapon called a Nail and magical powers called Spells. You will be able to upgrade your Nail and get new Spells as you progress through the game. You can also use the game's Charms, which are used to provide additional buffs to the player. Most new players will find the game quite difficult at first. Hollow Knights is much like the Dark Souls games, you don't get to choose the difficulty level and it's pretty unforgiving to make mistakes in battle. But the game is still very fun.

Hollow Knight has a very unique art style. Hollow Knight is not a high resolution game with realistic graphics. It is relatively simple, but it is a style that is instantly recognisable. When the player first arrives at the Dirtmouth, you immediately get a sense of destiny. The artist achieves this effect with a clever use of colour combinations. Each character and background was created using traditional animation where each image was drawn by hand.

Hollow Knight has a phenomenal original soundtrack. The music is composed by Christopher Larkin, an award-winning composer. The music in Hollow Knight follows the orchestral genre where a lot of string instruments like the cello are used but also instruments like the grand piano. The music in Hollow Knight is not only catchy but the music itself helps to tell the story. The music evolves along with the game and connects locations and characters. Larkin is truly a master in his work, he is incredibly good at weaving emotions into melodies. You can immediately see what he is trying to make you feel when you listen to his music.

The story is split around the entire game which I think is a very clever way of telling stories in games. It adds an aspect of mystery and really gets the player interested and intrigued. Some people think that not having a guide for a big open-world game is bad. But I think it gives the player more freedom, as the game encourages the player to discover everything themselves and play how they want. One disadvantage I could see is that the game can be very frustrating for those who get easily frustrated, as you can't choose the difficulty level. However, when I played, I never felt that any of the bosses were unfair. Every time I beat a boss, I get a sense of fulfillment.

Hollow Knight is an amazing game but not a game for everyone. For those who are looking for a challenging game with an interesting story, Hollow Knight is a must try game. But if you don't like being challenged in games or get easily frustrated, you can also just read about the game's story which is very interesting. With all the amazing music and art, it's hard to believe the game is only made by four people who got only 43, 000 USD on their Kickstarter for the game. I would give Hollow Knight a 10/10. A 10/10 is not perfect, because nothing is. But this game is the closest thing to perfect when it comes to this genre.

150112190.review:
Beautiful 2D combat platformer. There is so much to see and collect. The areas each have their own style and is beautifully hand-drawn. Great variety in enemies. The controls are tight. The game expects you to figure out some stuff on your own, which is both good and bad. I might be a moron for not figuring out how to use the purple bouncy mushrooms until I had ran around everywhere for a couple of hour, but still an amazing game. There are so many secrets and stuff you can miss on your first playthrough and you have to try to remember earlier deadends to find everything. It is classic Metroidvania gameplay, but since you don't need to go everywhere or get everything before you beat the final boss it is easy to miss content. I finished at about 22 hours and soon realized that there were a lot of stuff I missed so there is plenty of value for your money here.

TL;DR: Beautiful 2D Metroidvania. This is a must buy, even at full price (better to buy at a sale of course). The devs have added so much free content after the release, it is almost insane.

150048785.review:
A lot of the DLC stuff is not tested well and enemies have homing moves that make certain bosses cheap instead of difficult. Play it for the base game and Godhome is challenging, not fun.  The charms cost way too much to use and after about 100,000 dollars of money(geo) it becomes worthless. At the end I had too much money to spend on nothing. No consumables and just a lot of backtracking to try to get Dream Essence which does not drop enough. The game will give you around 2,000 for free and good luck getting anymore to drop without spending hours killing htings over and over or trying to stand still and use an extremely slow attack to increase your chances. 

I hated finding where the map seller was in every single location since there was barely any indication where to go. You would not know where to look unless you watched someone else play the game or have done multiple playthroughs.  The map is very much needed and to see where you are on the map you get a charm that requires a notch to use. A basic thing in most games costs you one "valuable" notch.  

A lot of stuff is well done of course, but the things done wrong are very awful and stick out like crazy.  Getting hit cancels healing, charging your attacks, and pushes you back and stops you from moving for one second.  Near the end of the dlc there are bosses that have 1-2 literal seconds for you to dodge their onslaught and hit them before they repeat their attacks again. You can get a healing charm that is garbage and costs 4 charm slots and takes 15 seconds to heal you IF YOU DON't GET HURT AGAIN.  On every boss you would need it on you might as well use something else. If you can manage to last 15 seconds not getting hit on an endgame boss, it's because you start to memorize all their patterns.  It's not hard, but then you realize you're doing more of a puzzle than an actual boss fight. The game forces you to use charged attacks (which are hidden) or spells that take way too much soul to use to hurt them a lot quickly so you don't have to repeat the same movements over and over 10 times, just 8 times.  

The onslaught doors where you fight multiple bosses you have fought before are  no issue until it adds bosses you haven't fought before at the VERY END. You do not get to heal unless you healed during the other fights or the "reset your charms" checkpoint that is not a checkpoint since if you die at any point... you start over.  So after x amount of minutes fighting all the bosses, you are thrown into an unknown super boss fight (unless you cheated and looked up videos and etc how to kill it) if you're going through the game the first time. Oop, didn't memorize all 14 attacks combinations they can do? Start over then.  Then to unlock more impossible fights, you have to bind your abilities and weaken yourself so much that fights become 4 times longer for EVERY BOSS.  Whoever tested the DLC (if anyone) did a terrible job.  

There's a difference between a game being "challenging and fun" than the devs putting a middle finger on the screen towards the player for them not researching and watching videos on how to fight a boss before they even fight it themselves.

149956834.review:
Pretty much the best metroidvania in existence, unparalleled both in scale and quality. Super Metroid and Symphony of the Night may have given the genre its very name, but Hollow Knight took it to a whole new level.

It’s much more accessible and never obtuse, but doesn’t sacrifice an ounce of their signature joy of discovery. It’s colorful and highly pleasant to look at, but still maintains a somber, melancholic atmosphere that’s dripping with mystery. It has a huge interconnected map and tons of activities to do, especially since 4 big content packs were released, but never even hints at becoming repetitive or stale. It’s combat is straightforward, with usually just a couple of attack patterns per boss, but that still somehow results in exceptionally memorable encounters (Mantis Lords / Sisters of Battle are pure flow). It used to have some optimization issues, but those too got addressed and are now nowhere to be seen.

The fact that most of it was developed by a team of 3 people makes it even more impressive. This is a rare case where such massive popularity feels less like a complicated interconnection of many inscrutable factors and more like a natural outcome of pure, consistent excellence. It’s nice to live in an age where we can get games like this.

P.S. MARKOOOOTH! *shakes fist*

149855111.review:
Hollow Knight is a Critically acclaimed game that deserves far more criticism than it gets. This game isn't anywhere close to perfect and there are quite a few flaws which can ruin the experience. For starters if you're not familiar with some of the techniques speedrunners often use in Metroidvania style games to sequence break, you don't need to read any further in this review. This game isn't for you. It will punish you. Hollow Knight is the absolute WORST metroidvania to pick as your first in the genre. But I'll discuss that more later.

Lets start with the good though, because the game does do a lot of things right. The Ambiance of the game, visuals and characters are all lovely. Its a well designed game with a lot of care put into how everything looks and how it feels. Personally, I'm not big on the art style but I can absolutely respect the vision and its execution. It very lovely. Lots of good little animations like when the player avatar looks down at the map when you open your map. Its details like this I absolutely adore! The goofiness of the characters is charming And I can see loving the game simply for its style. And from an artistic point of view, absolutely!

However, the Art style does have some serious problems with the world design. Because areas are very monochromatic and filled with a lot of negative space it can cause migraines for some of the audience that might want to play the game. I myself struggled through the game because the massive seconds filled mostly with negative space and its monochromatic style would give me migraines while playing it. It got so painful at one point playing the game I had to put down the game for several days because it hurt my eyes so bad. The only other games that have managed that were games styles after Atari or Nintendo Genesis era games so managing to cause this much pain for a more modern style game is impressive to say the least and absolutely not in a good way.

The Controls of the game are fine. They're standard for metroidvania games, other than the Nail bouncing there really isn't anything unique here. No Momentum for the character and we get a wall hope ability similar to Megaman X. I wish they took more from megaman X because that game actually has momentum in the movement with the dash skill. Hollow Knight's combat is perfectly fine for a metroidvania, but its also not impressive. And in some cases, its just inferior to combat in other games like Momodora or Ender Lilies. One might argue the bosses in Hollow Knight are better than both those games, but I strongly disagree. Only 1 boss in the entire game I'd say was actually all that good and the rest were just okay or outright terrible.

The Bosses in Hollow Knight are not all that good. A few of them are alright with a decent challenge to them while others are laughably easy. The best boss in the game I actually had fun fighting was the Mantis guys were I fight 3 of them in total. But I was either unimpressed with the rest of the bosses or the boss was so horrifically bad to fight with so much camera shake that it caused me so much physical pain to deal with I thought about quitting the game entirely.

Exploration of the world, usually my favorite part of any metroidvania game was an absolutely horrible experience at first and got tolerable once I learned that the game loves to suckerpunch you. What do I mean by that? Well, the game starts off and early in the game they have these enemies which lock onto you and slam into you at high speeds, even curving slightly. They're clearly inspired by the Skree from Metroid, however the Skree can easily be run past most the time in the first game and can be in the later games while in Hollow knight, their version will easily either come close to killing you or kill you outright. And they're positioned super early in the game before the player knows to expect rocket speed enemies which can kill you right off the bat. There's no warning for them, no time to realize you have to react to them, you just get blown up on right at the start. It gets worse starting out because it seems half the enemies explode in the early areas of the game, it seems like the game is not trying to be hard its just trying to punish you for not having precognition or cheating by reading a guide ahead of time.

Exploration gets even worse still because the Map and the compass are both upgrades. Because of the nature of the game and how exploration works the Map is actually something you can very easily miss. And with the fact the game takes all of your currency when you die and you need to recover it, added with the high price of the map you can quickly find yourself without a map and playing the game like the precursor to the entire Genre rather than a more modern Metroidvania which knows better than to tuck the map away from the player. Now, I don't necessarily think having to acquire a map is a bad idea. I think it can work in the right kind of Metroidvania. Hollow Knight isn't that Metroidvania and lacking a proper map for chunks of the game is dreadful. it was always "Okay, lets be cautious because I don't want to get cheated out of my cash before I find the map guy so I can afford it and get the map so I can FINALLY start to enjoy this game" which distracted me from what I really want to do, explore.

Exploration still gets worse and it goes into a topic I'll be covering next. You have this Notch system which is basically an equipment point system, its not the first game to use it it wont be the last but it is one of the worst versions of this system I've seen. How this relates to exploration is that in order to see your icon on the world map you need the compass which costs 1 point to equip. Now, You have very few slots throughout the game, even at the end a single point is a pretty big deal so to have one taken up by an ability that should be default is certainly a decision. A horrible decision that further punishes new players for not cheating by seeking outside help.

The Notch system itself is very poorly designed. Another point in its bad design is the nail length notches. This is something that honestly could have been its own upgrade. The player gets so few unique options with the notches as it is and a couple of them are actually just trap options like the thorn one.

But its not like we're done with the bad design either. If you die, not only do you lose all of your currency until you go back to collect it. Okay, that's fine, but we get 2 other punishments on top of that. First, you have to kill your shade to recover everything. Okay, that's not too bad, its not good, but its not the worst thing in the world. At least its not as terrible to fight as the Bat in Salt and Sanctuary. However it does do something WORSE than salt and sanctuary and that's the 3rd punishment which reduces your recovery pool until you kill the shade again. OH GREAT! So not only will you be struggling to get back to an area you die in for a reason but you're doing it weaker than you were before.

I mentioned above that you need to know how to sequence break to actually complete the game. Sequence breaks are typically the unintended method to completing a game faster than you're intended too. Sometimes Devs are aware you'll sequence break and will put Easter eggs for you like in Metroid Fusion, but to outright plan for the player to do it, this really takes the wind out of my sails. Rather than feeling like I've out maneuvered the game I'm playing it as intended and doing something a newbie to the genre might not even consider to try.

Now, I've ragged on the game long enough. I know a lot of people love the game, but the game is a hot mess. The game is hostile to the player and punishes you for not looking up a walkthrough. I went in blind and was heavily punished for playing it blind.

Even with my Criticism I do think the team behind it is talented and I'm cautiously optimistic for Silksong.

149790967.review: Pretty great metroidvania platforming game that offers tight controls. I thought I was over metroidvanias but this one proved me wrong. The physics and movement is what really makes this a strong game. Just moving around and wall hopping just feels so satisfying. It's also nice that there's a pseudo-hard difficulty you can pursue by going after optional bosses and side-quests. My biggest complaint about the game is that it didn't feel like a complete game until hours in when you finally get all of your tight platformer abilities (wall hopping / double jumping / dashing), the game felt incredibly dull for the longest time being only able to jump and attack without too many interesting level designs in my opinion. Forget the level designs later on because they're whatever but the controls are just so tight. Also sucks that things that should be built-into the game by default are things you have to workaround or equip, such as being able to see yourself on the map and being able to teleport with a portal because travelling back and forth constantly was more tedious than it was fun late-game. Doesn't have as much of a story as I'd like. Artstyle is neat. I like the Dark Souls influences in this game. Overall pretty good and would recommend.

149767728.review:
[b] TL;DR [/b]
Game is a 6/10 at best, not what I was advertised or what I was looking for.

Heard really high praise for this game, was recommended by many friends as "The greatest MetroidVania ever made". I love the genre and was excited for it.
This game has amazing art style, animation, atmosphere, music, the world is interesting and varied. It's gameplay however is luck luster at best, intentionally infuriating at the worst. Many decisions in regard to the gameplay seems to have 2 primary questions, "Will this be difficult" and "Will this waste the Players time". If the answer to both questions is "yes", then it made it into the game.

[b] Examples of minor time wasters that compound [/b]

Your Shade (Bloodstain) does not appear on the exact spot you died, but has preset locations per room. You also must kill the Shade to retrieve Geo/Soul Cairn, but the Shade is based on your power level so it will always die in a few hits, so why bother making it an enemy? No Coyote Time is ridiculous, especially because ledges often have grass or some other decoration masking the proper edge, leading to numerous falls when 99% of platformers would have allowed you that jump. Close to no I-frames on damage despite enemies being numerous and often quick, leading to chain deaths that are often impossible to break before you have the Dash. Fast Travel being separated into 3 forms each requiring their own unlock and use conditions.

[b] The Charms [/b]

Wayward Compass should be never have been a charm, at the very least make it a tool like the Lumefly Lantern. Nail Master's Glory is all but required to make Nail Arts usable, so why does it take a a slot instead of being a final upgrade from Sly? Stalwart Shell for damage I-frames is also ridiculous, as it should be a mechanic by default.

[b] Bosses [/b]

Keeping it simple, the bosses suck. I can count on 1 hand the bosses I enjoyed fighting, the other hand the bosses who were pushovers/tutorial, and the rest sucked all enjoyment out of the game. Nightmare Grimm/Grey Prince Zote/Nosk/Galien/Markoth in particular were awful. Most bosses end up in the not fun category for a simple reason; You spend most of your time dodging/chasing them down. The fights are a drag and personally I felt no sense of accomplishment after beating them beyond "Thank fuck I never have to do this again."

[b] The Map [/b]

The map is obtuse and mostly useless. Needing to rest to fill in the map only really serves to slow down exploration, since it will get filled in if you die and respawn anyway. Having to buy tokens individually and also limiting custom tokens to 6 per color unnecessarily limits and stretches out the navigation phase without making the game itself more fun. Finding each zones map inside the zone would be fine, but you also have to buy them once there, and the map itself doesn't mark room structure or completion. The compass being a charm (Albeit only 1 slot) is wholly unnecessary and frustrating when the map has so little information anyway.

[b] Expolration [/b]

Backtracking in this game is horrible, even by MetroidVania standards. Only 1 area changes over the course of the game and it has the least amount of content in it, areas are long and tedious to traverse with fast travel spread thin. The sheer amount of backtracking is absurd, the amount of times I had to go back to Deepnest or Kingdoms Edge, or pass through Fungal Wastes made me hate the zones. Add onto that that many "shortcuts" you unlock are 1-way, and thus cannot be used for quick traversal on return, only exit.
There is also next to no reward for exploration. Mask Shards/Soul Cairn pieces are few and far between, with Geo Deposits being the primary reward and occasionally a Charm or Grub. Many charms feel useless or won't fit an individuals playstyle, and only collectors will care about the Grubs. Money is plentiful and farmable very early, so Geo Deposits are meaningless for the majority of players. 
There was several times I explored an area, and got stuck with no option but to kill myself or Save&Quit. In particular, there was a passage in Crystal Peak where you need the Crystal Dash. I did not know this was an ability yet, so I tried to traverse the room with Dash/Pogo/Mantis Claw. I made it 3/4 into the room, and found I could no longer progress with my current tools, but also found that I could not return the same way I entered.
Many times I would have to jump down but be unable to see anything below, forcing a blind drop. Landing on spikes from these drops was not uncommon, and frustrating since the only way to know was take the initial risk.

[b] Conclusion [/b]

As a Platformer, this game fails to be challenging (Ignoring the Path of Pain, a completely optional and out of place difficulty spike) or engaging with it's movement. Lack of Coyote Time and poor visual clarity makes traversal frustrating.
As a MetroidVania, the obtuse map system and excessive backtracking remove most of the fun of exploring, and the lack of meaningful rewards/discoveries makes it a chore.

If you are looking for a MetroidVania or Platforming experience, I would never recommend this. If you want a Platform/Bullet Hell hybrid built on the boss fights alone, then this is your game.

149742016.review:
Hollow Knight is one of those rare games that has the perfect formula of storytelling, mystery, and stimulating game play. I would recommend this game to just about anyone looking to sink time into a good-quality single-player game; it is well worth the cost.

I do not usually play single-player games anymore, especially ones with challenging campaigns that throw you in the deep end. It's a game where there isn't an NPC holding your hand and pointing where to go. Your curiosity is the main driver for discovering how everything works.

It reminds us in some ways of an old Zelda game where you really need to work hard in order to discover the game and succeed. There is a shocking amount of detail and variety throughout the game, something that took me by surprise seeing that this is in the Indie category.

It took me 50 hours to complete the story line. There are certainly still components and alternate endings I am yet to explore that would increase that number. I played the entire game on the Steam Deck, and the default controller interface worked well.

149727884.review:
Base game with most of the updates is about a 20-40 hour experience of exquisite artworks and beautifully immersive environments. One environment is fairly dark and creepy, hearing tons of bugs crawling everywhere, but the rest of the game for the most part isn't scary. There's plenty of interesting environments and optional areas for a serene open world experience. The story is intriguing with about equal amounts of lore and your own interpretation, although there are plenty of youtube videos that provide context and theories.

The Godmaster update is basically 5 boss rushes. The last boss rush is 42 bosses in a row (and if you die, you start over). If you want a lore only optional item, you have to do those bosses with a bunch of handicaps. That run took me an hour and a half to do, with about 150 hours of failed attempts, but others have managed it in about 50 hours. If you do the boss rush without the handicaps, then it will take significantly less time, probably less than 20 hours.

Most people do not do the Godmaster update as it is disproportionately more difficult than the rest of the game and it's placed kind of out of the way.

As a word of caution if you want to do Godmaster. When I first tried doing the Godmaster update, I was using a wireless controller which not only introduced variable lag, but also rubbed and pressed into the side of my fingers. This constant rubbing eventually resulted in not just soreness, but my bones began thickening around the joints. Similar to rheumatoid arthritis (and I verified with the Dr that it was not that). I took a break for a few years from Hollow Knight hoping that my hands would heal and they did not, however they did not get any worse either. When I came back to the Godmaster update, I avoided this by using a keyboard as that doesn't bother my hands. But the moral of the story is, if your hand or fingers start hurting from doing Godmaster, find a different medium to play that doesn't hurt or don't do Godmaster.

149677843.review:
Hollow Knight isn't just a game; it's a mesmerizing journey that touched my heart and soul. From the moment I stepped into the enigmatic underground realm of Hallownest, I was spellbound. The game's breathtaking hand-drawn art style, a true labor of love, instantly drew me in. Each character and location is a work of art, and the hauntingly beautiful soundtrack added a layer of immersion that left me in awe. I found myself lost in the intricately designed world, where every corner told a story, and every enemy was a piece of a larger puzzle.

But what truly sets Hollow Knight apart is its gameplay. The challenging combat, precise controls, and the feeling of progression were a thrill. Every victory felt earned, and every defeat fueled my determination to become a better knight. The map's interconnected design and the thrill of discovering new areas and shortcuts added a sense of accomplishment that's hard to find elsewhere. The game's difficulty is perfectly balanced, offering a fair challenge that rewards skill and determination. Each epic boss battle and platforming challenge left me exhilarated.

As I ventured deeper into the darkness, the game's lore unfolded in a way that encouraged me to explore and piece together the story of Hallownest. The diverse cast of characters, both friend and foe, were unforgettable and enriched the narrative. The myriad of abilities and charms to acquire kept the gameplay fresh and exciting, letting me tailor my playstyle to my liking. Hollow Knight is a deeply emotional and artistic journey that demonstrates the incredible heights indie game developers can reach when they pour their hearts into their craft. If you love Metroidvania-style games, challenging combat, and a world you won't want to leave, then Hollow Knight is a must-play. It's a truly extraordinary adventure that has left an indelible mark on my gaming journey, and I'm excited for anyone about to dive into the depths of Hallownest.

I know I'm in the minority here, but I am so glad to be finished with this game. I wanted to like it, and on paper it looks just like my kind of thing; wonderful graphics, beautiful music, great combat, cool story, and all of that is good. The the actual navigation of the game though, the getting to and from places, is such a chore!

It takes you ages to get anywhere, and there are way too few fast travel points. I'm not saying every other room needs to have a fast travel point, but when there is something you have to come back to after getting a skill, or a difficult boss that takes several tries, you should NOT have to travel across half the map to get to it from the closest travel point. There were side quests I knew I could do but just didn't bother because travelling to it was such a chore.

While I know vagueness is part of Metroidvanias and you're supposed to figure out what to do for yourself, here it's simply too vague. This is made even more painful by the aforementioned traversal issues as you'll spend ages trying to get somewhere as the closest fast travel is three map sections away, only to find out the new ability you just got doesn't in fact let you into this new room. So back you go.

There is also a big challenge area that I thought you had to complete to progress. You don't. The game doesn't tell you this, I found out when trying to look up strategies as I'd spent hours on it.

To top all this off, I found myself hardly using the other attacks you learn. I found them all basically useless, apart from one or two specific moments. I only used the dash and the "hadoken" during the final boss. Similarly for all the charms, and there are a metric tone of them, maybe only eight or so are actually useful. 

The best way I can describe Hollow Knight is a pretty chore. It looks and sounds lovely, but actually playing it just is not that fun. Yes, I played through to completion of the main story (I achieved 79% overall completion) and I'm glad I can say I experienced it, but I'm happy to never play it again.

149638479.review: La realidad es que teniendo el tiempo que tiene no hay mucho que decir que no se haya dicho ya, pero bueno. Para empezar es uno de los mejores metroidvanias de la historia, para mí está en el top 3 de los que he jugado sin dudar. Como todos, tiene su backtracking y su necesidad de ir desbloqueando poderes para ir avanzando en el mapa y desbloqueando zonas y secretos, pero funciona de forma tan orgánica que cada nuevo descubrimiento se siente igual de emocionante que el primero. La banda sonora de Christopher Larkin es una verdadera maravilla, inmersiva en momentos más recogidos y de tintes épicos en los combates más críticos. Quizá uno de los mejores aspectos del juego sea lo satisfactorio de su control, cada salto, cada movimiento, dan la sensación de precisión y peso exactos, aunque no se sea un jugador experto en este tipo de juegos. La dificultad está bien medida, hay combates sencillos y otros más desafiantes, pero muchos son opcionales, por lo que la experiencia de juego se la plantea el propio jugador, sin tener que alterar ningún tipo de nivel de dificultad. La historia es tan maravillosa y críptica como la de cualquier Souls: si quieres saber más tendrás que rascar y estar muy atento, aunque al principio todo parezca excesivamente profundo y carente de sentido. El diseño de niveles es 10/10 (chef kiss), con constantes momentos de aaaaaah (después de abrir atajos o descubrir conexiones). El arte y los escenarios están también muy trabajados y en una consonancia con la genial banda sonora que también es sobresaliente. En resumen, es la segunda vez que lo juego después de terminarlo en Switch hace un par de años y en esta run en busca del 112% me lo estoy gozando tanto o más que en la primera así que, si has llegado hasta aquí, que duda cabe que voy a decir, cómprate esta maravilla, lo sorprendente es que sea tan barato un juego que ofrece tantísimo.

149632677.review:
This is everything that I enjoy about a video game, and if you enjoy these types of things as well, you should definitely play this game. I have put over 260 hours into this game on steam, and hundreds more on PS4. The Artwork and Themes and the Challenging Game Play are by far the most prominent of the elements of Hollow Knight. This game is popularly played on keyboard and mouse, and that works excellently, but a controller works amazingly as well, and it's usually my go to.

The World that your set in is filled with bugs, but they have spirit and characteristics that will make you enjoy them. The 2D Artwork that describes and brings the environment to your screen is so well done, each part of this game is beautifully drawn, even the simple sections have detail. The world, the adventuring and exploring, the unique settings and elements of each section will entertain you throughout the entire game. Once you've finished the game, it's a game you can come back to and explore the world all again! Every character, enemy, and boss is thoughtfully designed and you can really engage with the aesthetic of the game all the way through. The NPCs of this game make the world feel complete with little bits of lore spread throughout the game. but also, you can skip right over them if you want. If art and game worlds are not your thing, it won't get in the way of the game play!

The GAME PLAY and MECHANICS of this game are very well thought out. The game takes advantage of its 2D elements and uses that to create some excellent fighting and platforming mechanics. If you really don't like platforming, this game won't satisfy your mechanical preferences, but you will enjoy this game if you can enjoy platformers. The COMBAT of this game is amazing. You can progress through this game without insanely high skill, because you can gain different items and increase your spell casting abilities, as well as strengthen your blade. However, it also gives players quite a challenge, and there are optional fights and battles that increase in difficulty. Some are necessary to keep exploring and progressing through the game, and some are there just for the fun of it. There is also a place in the game where there are nothing but bosses, which is very engaging if you like non-stop combat.

Overall, this game is very well made. If the kinds of the things that are in this game aren't your thing, it's not an absolutely must play. But if you like these types of things, you will really enjoy it. This is my favorite game, so I'm trying to give it even more good reviews!

149586035.review:
I cannot with clear conscience recommend Hollow Knight, it may be a good game under certain circumstances, but I disagree with the direction that was taken here. The game was marketed to me as a metroidvania with soulslike mechanics and while it may be a very good metroidvania and even that could be debatable, for example I had much more fun playing Unepic than this game, from soulslike games it took all the wrong lessons, which I will go into later into review. Compared to let us say Salt and Sanctuary, which should be the same genre, there is no really no comparision. Salt and Sanctuary copied everything about Dark Souls in a way kind of like a Japan with America after WWII with a mentality of I have no idea why this works so great, so let us copy everything. Hollow Knight took a look at Dark Souls and copied just a few surface aspects for no reason at all.

First of all, the story. Yes, Dark souls can get very mystical. Yes, Dark Souls gives you only the very basic information. Yes, Dark Souls story is very basic. All of these are true, but you get none of it in Hollow Knight. I have no idea why am I the MC where I am, why do I fight with all these monsters and even what is my end goal. You can say Dark Souls is the same, you can go whereever and do whatever which is true in a way, but the first NPC you meet tells you to ring two bells of awakening and afterwards you get another overarching objective of collecting Lord Souls and if you stray and explore you can get some cool loot or epic locations. In Hollow Knight you meet mysterious NPC at the start, who tells you nothing relevant and I am rewarded with mysterious hints when exploring, so there is really no reason to explore, since you are even getting punished for exploration by enemies instantly respawning when you leave and enter the same room again.

Next the currency. Similiar to Dark Souls you get a currency here for killing enemies. In Dark Souls however you may use the currency to upgrade your stats from the start, such a thing is not here in the Hollow Knight, only able to buy QoL upgrades like new pins on a map. What is then the point of losing this currency upon death in Hollow Knight you may ask? Well, there is no point really. If you die in Dark Souls it is a precious resource you can use to upgrade your power, so you do not want to lose that, in Hollow Knight you just shrug and move on if you lose it. Also even at the start since you can only buy QoL stuff, you will have nothing to spend it on, which can never happen in Dark Souls and if you lose it, you have only yourself to blame. Why then if you want to punish player for dying (which in itself is a punishment) are you not able to just load his last position at the bench with the currency he had back then, if you want to invalidate his progress and teach him to save frequently like was the norm in the games in the past?

And now that I am on that topic. Save points/benches/bonfires whatever you want to call that. Why do you have boss runs in Hollow Knight? In Dark Souls it works because you have limited amount of healing, which means anytime you get to the boss area with more healing items than the last time, you have an advantage that you gained by playing better, it is designed as a challenge every time. You gain nothing with boss runs in Hollow Knight, they are just pointlessly tedious.

I could probably even go on with problem solving that the game offers you with different weapons, blocks, parries, dodges etc. but I have not managed to get far enough to really comment on that, but let us just say that I do not have very good opinion of the combat and I think my point with the Dark Souls comparisions was made. There is nothing soulslike about this game.

Based on all the praise I've seen for this game alongside the fact I love metroidvania games, I really want to love this game but I just can't. For the most part it's a really solid game, but there are some design flaws that make the game frustrating enough that I've uninstalled it 15 hours in.
- projectiles you're supposed to deflect that can and often will damage you even when you successful deflect them
- the fact that some enemies can hit you while you're stunned, meaning you can in some areas go from full heath to dead from effectively a single hit
- the fact you can suddenly be hit from offscreen by enemies you had no way of knowing even existed, which in some areas can knock you off platforms and to your death
I'm not going to list everything but there are many other things that I personally find make this game too frustrating to be worth it. Maybe it's being on Steam Deck that's causing so many issues. Regardless, I uninstalled the game after I died to a boss because twice in a row it started a cutscene while I was healing, wasting my healing resources without healing me and leaving me unable to heal, and then after another cutscene the boss killed me by hitting me twice while I was still frozen in place. As charming as this game can be and as much as I want to finish the story, all of the bs and the frustration it causes makes it simply not worth it.

1. Precalentar el horno 180° (350°F).
2. Preparar un molde rectangular, cubrir con mantequilla o aceite en spray e idealmente con papel para hornear.
3. Batir el azúcar, aceite y huevos.
4. Agregar las zanahorias ralladas, luego los ingredientes secos nuez moscada, canela, sal, polvos de hornear y harina.
5. Unir todo bien y llevar al horno a la misma temperatura por 45 minutos.
6. Si le falta cocción, tape con papel de aluminio para seguir con el horneado, así evitará que se le queme por encima.
7. Una vez listo, dejar que se enfríe antes de desmoldar.
8. Si gustan pueden cubrir el queque con un simple glacé, mezclando 3/4 taza de azúcar flor con una o dos cucharadas de jugo de naranja. Esto es opcional.

Is this game hard? Oh yeah definetly. Is there a difficulty setting? Nope. Do I normally like difficult games? Absolutely not. You can see the lil thumbs up.

The cost for dying is relatively low, so long as you can get back to where you were without dying you lose nothing. If you don't think you can then there is always an option to get your items back in the safest part of the game. 

I struggled with SO many bosses on my first tries, but with upgrades and learning and many attempts the success felt amazing. Going back to the early bosses I once struggled so much with (and even some later ones) and finding them so incredibly easy? God that makes me proud.

149345988.review:
The appeal that got me to purchase this game was its wide array of bosses and its art style. Once I started playing, however, what really impressed me was the world-building and music. 

The world reminds me of a nightmarish world that isn't scary at all. Rather, it's a nightmarish world that makes you curious to discover more. Kinda backward, isn't it? I don't always see "dark" portrayed as something exciting to explore and almost welcoming. There's something about the ambiance of this game, in conjunction with the awesome music, that make it feel simultaneously "cozy" and "this world has SO many places to discover". I don't know how else to explain it simply, but this aspect of the game was its strongest trait, in my opinion.

I find the narrative itself to be quite great, albeit a little unclear if it weren't for the help of Wiki articles and Youtube videos. That's not necessarily a mark down though. I'd rather be shown a lot of interesting things and told little than be told everything and shown anything worth noting. That said, I found myself needing to reread some NPC's key moment dialogues to fully grasp what they were talking about.

The music is AWESOME and really aids the game in its favor. Many of the key things that make me enjoy this game the most are due to how the music works with the rest of the game. Christopher Larkin did a great job with making the music match the scene.

Also the CHARACTER DESIGNS? I have no words there. Super duper creative. *chef's kiss*

The difficulty curve is also handled quite well. It never felt like things were getting too hard too quick, but I never felt like I wasn't being challenged.

There were one or two spots in the game in my first play-through where I had gotten INCREDIBLY frustrated over not understanding where I could go next. ([spoiler]Specifically, after defeating the Soul Master in the City of Tears's Soul Sanctum, as well as understanding how to enter the Hive.[/spoiler]) There's quite a bit of content I probably never would have found, including key bits essential for progressing in the game, had I not consulted help from the internet, but I think that's more on me as a player than it is the game itself.

All in all, Hollow Knight is a great game worthy of being as popular as it is.

149340010.review:
Hollow Knight is a masterpiece in the world of indie gaming, a shining example of what a small development team can achieve when passion and creativity are combined. This enchanting game has left an indelible mark on the gaming community, and I can't help but share my overwhelmingly positive thoughts about it.

From the moment you step into the dark and mysterious underground world of Hallownest, Hollow Knight's enchanting art style and ambiance will capture your heart. The hand-drawn, beautifully detailed environments, combined with hauntingly atmospheric music, create an immersive experience that is nothing short of mesmerizing. The world of Hallownest feels alive with its quirky inhabitants, mysterious lore, and a sense of foreboding wonder that beckons you to explore every nook and cranny.

The gameplay in Hollow Knight is equally exceptional. The game offers a beautifully balanced blend of challenging combat and exploration. As the titular Hollow Knight, you'll navigate intricate levels, face off against unique and formidable foes, and solve intricate platforming puzzles. The precision of the controls and the responsiveness of the combat mechanics make every encounter a rewarding experience, and mastering the game's numerous abilities is a true pleasure.

What truly sets Hollow Knight apart is its open-ended, non-linear world. Players are free to explore Hallownest at their own pace, uncovering hidden secrets and uncovering a captivating narrative. The game's cryptic storytelling, told through cryptic dialogues, environmental clues, and item descriptions, invites players to piece together the rich lore of the world.

Additionally, the game's boss battles are a highlight. Each boss fight is a unique challenge that requires strategy and skill. The satisfaction of conquering these formidable foes is immensely rewarding, and the diverse range of bosses keeps the game feeling fresh and exciting throughout.

Furthermore, Hollow Knight offers tremendous replay value. With multiple endings, a plethora of collectibles, and optional challenges, there's always something more to discover and achieve, making it an ideal game for completionists and those who crave a long-lasting experience.

In conclusion, Hollow Knight is a shining jewel in the world of video games. Its breathtaking art, engaging gameplay, and immersive storytelling make it a must-play title for anyone who appreciates the medium. Team Cherry, the developers, have crafted a truly remarkable and unforgettable experience, and the game continues to receive love and support from both the community and the developers themselves. Hollow Knight is a testament to the boundless creativity and dedication of indie game developers, and it's an experience that will leave a lasting impact on anyone who ventures into the world of Hallownest.
